Toxicity and Side Effects:
1. Emotion/neurologic: headaches, insomnia, anxiety. (2, 3, 4)
2. Circulatory/respiratory: pale face, purple lips, spastic limbs, elevated blood pressure, rapid respiration, exhaustion and death. (2, 3, 4)
3. May cause edema.
4. Other side effects: hiccups, itchy skin. (2)

General toxicity: Natural saponins are highly toxic; the toxicity of ginseng saponins is relatively mild. Oral dosage of 100 ml of 3% ginseng tincture may cause anxiety and over-stimulation. Oral dosage of 200 ml may cause allergic reactions of rash, itchiness, dizziness, headache, rising of body temperature and bleeding. There is a report of death after orally taking 500 ml. (1)

Drug interaction: Eleutherosides of ginseng are related to digitalis glycosides (e.g., digoxin) and may have an additive effect with digoxin. Concurrent use of digitalis glycosides and ren shen (ginseng) may increase serum levels of digoxin and possible digitalis glycoside toxicity.

Pregnancy: May not be suitable during pregnancies.

Part-specific caution: Stalks of ginseng plants contain large amounts of calcium oxalate. Calcium oxalate can combine with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to form oxalic acid, which is toxic and can promote nausea and vomiting. The stalk cannot substitute ginseng in application.

Processing/handling: Do not use microwave oven to heat ginseng.

Adulteration/substitution warning: Since ginseng is expensive and difficult to produce, adulteration or substitution is common. Some manufactured "ginseng" products contain Mandragora officinarum (mandrake) with hyoscine bromide, rauwolfia alkaloids with reserpine, cola with caffeine, phenylbutazone (a carcinogen), and aminopyrine. An independent test commissioned by the journal “Whole Foods” found that 60% of ginseng products contained too little herb to have biological effect; 25% contained no ginseng at all.

Fake substitute: Hua-shan shen (華山參) resembles ren shen in shape and color. Distribution: Shaanxi, Shanxi, Henan. It is hot and poisonous. Although used medicinally (calming, cough suppression, cold-type diarrhea), decoction dosage is very small: 0.3–0.9 g. Dosages over 1 g can be toxic. Early clinical symptoms: dry mouth, dry tongue, difficulty swallowing, excitement, hallucination, flushing without sweat, dilated pupils, vomiting, dizziness, manic and delirium. Late-stage symptoms: slowed breathing, raised body temperature with cold extremities, whole-body spasm, coma, and even death.
Research:
Anti-cancer: Contains a variety of saponins, ginseng polysaccharide, and ginseng volatile oil, which possess anti-cancer effects. Saponins of red ginseng can induce cancer cells to re-differentiate into non-cancer cells. [208]{209}

Ginsenoside-Rh2 significantly inhibits human promyelocytic leukemia HL-60 cell strains.

Panax ginseng leaves extract can inhibit the in vitro growth rate and division ability of human gastric cancer cells, increasing intracellular glycogen content, decreasing intracellular mucopolysaccharide and phosphatase activity, thereby inhibiting gastric cancer cell growth, division rate, and proliferation.

Long-term oral administration of red ginseng extract reduces the carcinogenic effects in mice of urethane (ethyl carbamate), N-methyl-N-nitrite base - N-guanidine nitrate, DMBA (7,12-dimethylbenz[α]anthracene), aflatoxin and other chemical substances.

CNS mechanisms: Possesses central cholinergic-like and catecholaminergic-like activities; enhances cholinergic system function, increases acetylcholine (Ach) synthesis and release, and increases central M-cholinergic receptor density. [28]

Anti-aging: Nursing bees with Chinese ginseng flowers significantly extended life span by about 10–15 days. [140]

Sexual function: Ginsenosides can facilitate penile erection by directly inducing vasodilatation. [2]

Infectious disease model (animal): Ginseng treatment reduces bacterial load and lung pathology in chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa pneumonia in rats. [3]

Cognition (humans): Improves the cognitive performance of Alzheimer’s disease patients. [4]

Hepatic: Protective effect of ginseng components toward liver fibrosis. [5]

Stability/processing: Freeze drying can prevent degradation of its saponins.

Cognition and glycemia: Effects of Panax ginseng, consumed with and without glucose, on blood glucose levels and cognitive performance during sustained “mentally demanding” tasks can enhance cognitive performance. [0]
Notes:
hong shen (紅參, red ginseng): processed product made by steaming the cultivated ginseng (圓參) and drying the root. Harvested in autumn, washed, steamed, then dried.

Saponins: Plant glucosides that form soapy lathers when mixed and agitated with water; used in detergents, foaming agents, and emulsifiers. Most plant saponins are toxic and can cause hemolysis, but ginseng saponins are mild and almost do not have that effect. The chemical structures of ginseng saponins are completely different from saponins of other plants; the term ginsenoside (人參皂甙) was created to distinguish them.

Ginsenoside classification: According to characteristics and chemical structures, ginsenosides are divided into three groups: Protopanaxadiol (PD): ginsenoside-Rb1 is an important ingredient and possesses CNS inhibition; Protopanaxatriol (PT): ginsenoside-Rg1 is an important ingredient and possesses CNS stimulation; Oleanolic acid (齊墩果烷酸): saponins of most plants belong to this group. The effects of PD and PT are opposite but do not cancel each other.

Price and quality: Wild ginseng roots cost much more than cultivated roots; no fixed market price for good quality wild roots. Chinese Manchuria wild ginseng roots fetch the highest retail prices. Wild roots from Jilin used to fetch the highest price; products labeled "Jilin ren shen" now sell for modest prices, less than Korean ginseng. A good wild Jilin root of about 50 g can sell for US $15,000. Top quality American wild roots can fetch $600–$1,200 per pound; cultivated American roots sell for $60–$120 per pound. Price fluctuation is determined more by supply; demand for cheaper quality is more elastic, for higher quality more inelastic.

Morphology differences: Wild roots usually are not symmetrical and are denser than cultivated ones; often not straight due to uneven wild soil. Cultivated roots are more symmetrical, straighter, and softer; ring marks are less dense and roots are less fragrant. Wild roots have more small, thin, hair-like whiskers; cultivated roots have fewer due to watering and fertilization. Reported fraud: whiskers from American wild roots have been trimmed and re-attached to cultivated Chinese or Korean roots to imitate wild; whiskers fall off when cooked.

Market forms: Sold in powder, capsules, and extract in the West (mainly to non-Oriental markets). Better quality roots are usually sold as intact roots; analogy given that better cuts (tenderloin or filet mignon) are not made into hamburger.

Geography: Han fang ji (fen fang ji) is distributed in Zhejiang, Anhui, Jiangxi, Hubei provinces.
Guangdong mu fang ji (guang fang ji) is distributed in Guangdong and Guangxi provinces.
Maladies Treated: Inflammation of nerves (Japanese han fang ji used as pain reliever).
Stiffness of the shoulders (Japanese han fang ji used as pain reliever).
Gout (Japanese han fang ji used as pain reliever).
Back pain (Japanese han fang ji used as pain reliever).
Trigeminal neuralgia (三叉神经痛) (Chinese han fang ji).
Edema (as a diuretic) (Chinese han fang ji).
Medical Function: Analgesic: used as a pain reliever (Japanese han fang ji).
Diuretic effect (Chinese han fang ji).
Diuretic effect (mu fang ji).
Relieves pain of nerve inflammation (mu fang ji).
Dosage: 5–10 grams, boiled with water. 5~10 克，作煎劑。

Indications: Treats anemia, low back pain, contracture, limb soreness, cold extremities. Applied to frostbite, intestinal hernia pain, lumbago, beriberi, abdominal pain due to the uterus and its accessory organs.
Composition: Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root), Gui Zhi (Cinnamon twig), Shao Yao (Peony root), Mu Tong (Akebia stem), Da Zao (Jujube), Xi Xin (Asarum), Gan Cao (Licorice).
Contraindications:
Using hanfangchin A for injection should not exceed 300 mg to avoid toxicity.

Guang fang ji is produced in Guangdong and is also called Guangdong mu fang ji. It belongs to the Aristolochiaceae family and is toxic for the kidneys. 30 g is the toxic dosage.

The whole plant of Guangdong mu fang ji (Aristolochiae fangchi) is toxic. Animals or people eating the fresh stems, leaves, or flowers can show symptoms of headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, difficulty in breathing, numbness in limbs. See ma dou ling.

Large dosages and/or long-term usage of Aristolochia fangchi (guang fang ji) is toxic to the kidneys.

Note regarding formulas: Fu Ke Fen Qing Wan (婦科分清丸) appears on an FDA warning site, but the classical formula does not contain mu tong (Akebia stem), fang ji, or xi xin (Asarum), any of which may contain aristolochic acid. The version listed by Zhongguo Yaodi (China Materia Medica) contains Guan Mu Tong (Aristolochiae manshuriensis) or Aristolochia debilis and is toxic to the kidneys.
Research:
Lab animals receiving sinomenin injections showed increased reflex functions, spasms, paralysis, and death (animal study).

Chinese han fang ji showed that it can regulate body temperature.

Fen fang ji jian (粉防己鹼, tetrandrine) is a calcium channel blocker and has bidirectional regulatory effects on calcium-activated potassium channels. Beyond known actions on the cardiovascular system—antihypertensive, antiarrhythmic, and coronary vasodilation—it also has the following pharmacological actions: anti-myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury, anti-pulmonary arterial hypertension, anti-proliferation of vascular smooth muscle, anti-hypertrophy of cardiomyocytes, and regulation of the release of cardiovascular active substances.
Notes:
Historically, those produced in the Han Zhong area were called han zhong fang ji and belonged to the Aristolochiaceae family. Today, when the herb fang ji passes through the area of Han Kou, it is called Han fang ji; thus it is not a single variety of plants.

In prescriptions, if it is written simply as "fang ji" and does not specify "mu fang ji," it is usually deemed to be "fen fang ji."

Han fang ji (Radix Stephaniae tetrandrae: Tetrandrine C38H42N2O6 (漢防己甲素; 漢防己鹼, 粉防己鹼).
Mu fang ji (Radix Cocculus trilobus): Cocculolidine (葉含木防己葉酸 [衡州烏藥裡定鹼]) (present in leaves).
